editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE COSTLIE WHORE. A COMICALL HISTORIE, Acted by the companie of the Revels.
LONDON Printed by Auguſtine Mathewes, for WILLIAM SHEARES, and are to be ſold at his ſhoppe in Brittaines Burſe. 1633.

sp.speaker: Conſtantine.
sp.p: HOw do'ſt thou like the lovely Euphrata?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Then thou didſt not marke
The faireſt Saxon Lady in mine eye,
That ever breath'd a maid.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: Your minde now knowne,
Ile ſay ſhee is the faireſt in the world,
Were ſhe the fouleſt.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Then thos canſt diſſemble.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: You know I cannot, but deare Conſtantine,
I prethee tell me firſt, what is that Ladie?
That wonder of her ſexe, cal'd Euphrata,
Whoſe daughter is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: I cannot blame thee Otho.
Though thou be ignorant of her high worth,
Since here in Saxon we are ſtrangers both,
But if thou cal'ſt to minde, why we left Meath,
Reade the trice reaſon in that Ladies eye,
Daughter unto the Duke of Saxonie,
Shee unto whom ſo many worthy Lords,
Vail'd Bonnet, when ſhe paſt the Triangle,
Making the pavement Ivory where ſhe trode.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: She that ſo lightly toucht the marble path,
That leadeth from the Temple to the preſence.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: The ſame.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: Why that was white before,
White Marble Conſtantine, whiter by odds
Then that which lovers terme the Ivory hand,
Nay then the Lillie, whiteneſſe of her face.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Come, thou art a cavilling companion,
Becauſe thou ſeeſt my heart is drown'd in loue,
Thou wilt drowne me too, I ſay the Ladie's faire,
I ſay I love her, and in that more faire,
I ſay ſhe loves me, and in that moſt faire,
Love doth attribute in Hyperbolies,
Vnto his Miſtris the creation of every excellence,
Becauſe in her his eies do dreame of perfect excellence,
And here ſhe comes.
Obſerve her, gentle friend.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Welcome ſweete Conſtantine.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: My Euphrata.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Thy Euphrata, be thou my Conſtantine,
But what is he a ſtranger, or thy friend?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: My ſecond ſelfe, my ſecond Euphrata,
If thou beeſt mine, ſalute her gentle Otho.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: An humble and a true devoted heart,
I tender to you in a mindes chaſt kiſſe.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Welcome to me, ſince welcome to my friend.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: A beautifull, an admirable Ladie,
I thinke 'tis fatall unto every friend,
Never to love, untill his friend firſt love,
And then his choice; but ſooner will I teare
Out of this breſt, mine affection with my heart.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Hearing ſweet Conſtantine thou wert ſo nere me,
I came as I were wing'd to gaze on thee.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: And would to heaven there were no barin time
To hinder me from thy deſired ſight,
But thouſand ſutors eyes do watch my ſteps,
And harke I heare ſome trampling, how now Iulia?

sp.speaker: Iuli.
sp.l: Madam, the Lord Montano ſpying you,
To leave the preſence, and to enter here,
Hath ever ſince waited your comming foorth,
And will not be denied untill he ſee you.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Of all my ſutors, moſt importunate.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: What is he love?

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Of very noble birth.
But my affection is not tyed to birth,
I muſt diſpenſe with this kind conference,
For ſome ſmall time, untill I rid him hence,
Therefore within my cloſet hide thy ſelfe,
Your friend ſhall Iulia guide into the garden,
Where through a private doore, but ſeldome vs'd,
He may at pleaſure leave us and returne,
Deny me not, I prethee Conſtantine,
Thou haſt my heart, and would thy birth were ſuch,
I need not feare t'avouch thee for my Love.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: Madam, I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Farewell deare friend,
Returne as ſoone as may be, farewell Love.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Now guide Montano hither.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Gracious Madam, I have ſeene the noble Palſgrave,
The Prince of Milleine, and the Palatine of the Rheine,
With divers other honorable ſutors,
Mounted to ride unto their ſeverall places.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Of me they tooke their farewell yeſternight.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: What meanes your grace to be ſo unkind to all?
You drive away good fortune by diſdaine.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Why are you grieving too?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I am your ſubiect;
The meaneſt that did humbly ſeeke your love,
Yet not the meaneſt in affection,
And I am come to take my farewell too.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Why then farewell.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: So ſhort with them that love you.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Your journey may be great for ought I know,
And 'tis an argument of little love,
To be the hinderer of a traveller.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: My journey Madame is unto my houſe,
Scarce halfe a league hence, there to pine and die,
Becauſe I love ſuch beauteous crueltie.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: God ſpeede you ſir.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Nay then I will not leave you:
Madam, 'tis thought, and that upon good ground
You have ſhrin'd your affection in the heart
Of ſome (what ere he be) noble, or baſe,
And thats the cauſe you lightlie cenſure all.

sp.speaker: Euphr.
sp.l: Who thinkes it?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I doe Madame, and your father.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: It is upon my vowed chaſtitie.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: What devill made you ſweare to chaſtitie,
Or have you tane that oath onely for a terme.

sp.speaker: Euphr.
sp.l: A terme, what terme?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: A terme of ſome ſeven yeeres,
Or peradventure halfe the number more.

sp.speaker: Euphr.
sp.l: For terme of life.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: You have ſworne to be forſworne,
He was no well diſpoſed friend of yours,
That gave you conſaile to forſweare ſuch beautie,
Why tis as if ſome traveiler had found
A mine of gold, and made no vſe of it.
For terme of life; why then die preſently,
So ſhall your debt to nature be farre leſſe;
Your tyranny over mans yeelding heart
Be leſſe condemned: oh you were made for man,
And living without man, to murder men:
If any creature be ſo fortunate
That lives in grace of your all gracious ſelfe,
Though I am well perſwaded 'tis not I
I vow by all the rites of vertuous love,
Be he ignoble, of the baſeſt ſort,
To pleaſe you Madame, Ile renounce my ſuite,
And be a ſpeciall meane unto your father,
To grant your hearts affection, though I die.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Now Lord Montano you come neere my heart,
And were I ſure that you would keepe your word,
As I am ſure you love me by your deedes,
I might perchance deliver you my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: By heaven, and by your beauteous ſelfe I will.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Then Conſtantine come forth, behold thy friend.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Madame what meane you, to reveale our love?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: This is a very ſtubborne Gentleman,
A Gentleman, a peſant, Saxonie affords not one more baſe.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: He does me wrong, that termes me meaner then a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I tearme thee ſo.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Why how now Lord Montano, you do forget your oath.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: And you your ſelfe,
Your Princely father, and the Dukedomes honour.
To chaine your liking to a groome ſo baſe.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: He lies that calles me groome.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: O God, forbeare,
His Excellence, your father's comming hither.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: He comes in happie time, to know the cauſe,
Why ſuch great Princes have bin made your ſcorne.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: What will you tell him?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Will I? let me die
Contemn'd of heaven, in publique obloquie,
If I reveale not this laſcivious courſe.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: We are undone.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Hence with this prating Maide,
If thou haſt any anger in thy breſt,
Towards this Lady, turne it all on me,
She is a woman, timerous by her kinde,
I man-like borne, and beare a man-like minde.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Ile trie your courage — draw.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: As thou fear'ſt my frowne,
As thou haſt hope to thrive in thy new choice,
As thou reſpect'ſt the favour of the gods,
Welfare in any action thou intends,
Doe not reveale unto my fretfull father
This humble choice that my high birth hath made.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Why then forſweare him.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Sooner ſet thy feet
Vpon my breaſt, and tread me to the ground.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: As thou art any thing more then a beaſt.
Doe not procure my Ladie ſuch diſgrace.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Peace bawde, Ile have no conference with you.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: He cannot hurt me, 'tis my Love I feare,
Although my father be as ſterne as warre,
Inexorable like conſuming fire,
As iealous of his honour, as his crowne,
To me his anger is like Zephires breath,
Caſt on a banke of ſommer violets:
But to my Love, like whirlewinde to a boate,
Taken in midſt of a tumultuous ſea.
sp.stage: Enter Duke of Saxonie, and Fredericke.
sp.l: Alas he comes, Montane, prethee peace,
Courage ſweete Love.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I ſee our love muſt ceaſe.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Not if my wit can helpe,
It ſhall goe hard but Ile prevent the traitor.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Heare me my Lord.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Heare me my gracious father.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Heare me my liege, ther's treaſon in your Court,
I have found a peaſant in the Princeſſe cloſet,
And this is he that ſteales away her honour.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: This villaine gracious father 'tis that ſeekes
To rob me of mine honor, you your daughter.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Now as you are a right heroike Prince,
Be deafe unto your daughters faire words.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Be deafe to him, as you regard your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What ſtrange confuſion's this, that cloyes our hearing?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Speake beauteous ſiſter, who hath done thee wrong?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Her ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: This traitor.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Lord Montano.

sp.speaker: Euphr.
sp.l: Hee.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Villaine thou dyeſt.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Stay, ſhe meanes Conſtantine,
Hee that I found infolded in her cloſet,
Reaping the honour, which a thouſand Lords
Have fail'd in ſeeking, in a lawfull courſe.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: He does me wrong my gracious ſoveraigne.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: He wrongs my Ladie, an't pleaſe your grace.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Ile tell the trueth.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Or rather let me tell it.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Laſcivious love is ever full of ſleights.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Villaines that ſeeke by treaſon their deſires,
Want no ſuggeſtion to beguile a trueth.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Iſay, I found this peaſant in her cloſet,
Kiſſing, imbracing, and diſhonouring her.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: I ſay, an'c pleaſe your gracious Excellence.
I found this Gentleman within my cloſet,
There ſet by ſubornation of this Lord,
And here appointed to diſhonor me,
Speake, is't not true?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: True, if it pleaſe your grace.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What ſay you ſtrumpet?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Since my Ladie ſaies ſo,
I ſay and't pleaſe your Excellence.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Speake woman.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: 'Tis very true.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: O monſtrous forgerie.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: O more then falſhood to become ſo ſmooth,
In ſuch a dangerous action.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: This is ſtrange,
Montano ſeeke the ruine of my daughter.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Becauſe I would not yeeld unto his ſuite,
Which hee in rapefull manner oft hath ſought,
Hee ſet this Gentleman to doe me ſhame,
Intending by exclaimes to raiſe the Court,
But that repentance in my waiting Maide,
And of his ſorrowfull ſelfe, reveal'd the plot.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: O ye gods, how am I over-reacht!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I know the yong man to be well diſcended,
Of civill carriage, and approved faith,
How ere ſeduced to this enterpriſe.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: My conſcience would not propagate that plot.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: Nor mine my Lord, though gold corrupted me.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Cleane from the byas wit, by heaven rare wit,
Ile tell another tale, if they have done.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What canſt thou ſpeake vild traitor,
Thou ſeeſt thou art prevented in thy plot,
And therefore deſperately coin'ſt any thing,
But I am deafe to all ſuch ſtratagems.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Will you not heare me?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Forgeries and lies,
My daughters honour is of that high prize,
That I preferre it 'fore a traitors braine,
Let it ſuffice, we know ſhe hath deni'd thee,
And ſome denied (like devills) turne their love,
Into excrutiation of themſelves,
And of the parties whom they have belou'd;
Revenge begins where flatteries doe end,
Being not her husband, thou wilt be no friend.
Thus is thy policy by heaven prevented,
Therefore henceforth, we baniſh thee our Court,
Our Court? our territorie, every place,
Wherein we beare the ſtate of Royaltie:
Vrge no replie, the fact is plainely prou'd,
And thou art hatefull where thou wert belou'd.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: My gracious Lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: We can afford no grace,
Stay there, and reade thy ruine in my face.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I goe, contented with this heavy doome
'Twas mine owne ſeeking, faire, and wiſe adiew,
Deceit hath kil'd conceit, you know tis true.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: An vpright ſentence of an act ſo vilde.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Remove this waiting virgin from your chamber,
But let this gentleman attend on me,
The beſt may be deceiu'd by trecherie.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Then ſo my gracious father may this maid.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Then let her keep her place, beware of gold,
Honour's too precious to be baſelie ſold.
Now to our dying friend, his grace of Meath,
Daughter prepare you, you ſhall ride along,
For to that end we came, come ſonne to horſe,
Ere we come there, our friend may prove a coarſe.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Twas well done both, this action rarely fell,
Where women trie their wits, bad plots prove well.
1. Come away fellow louſe, thou art ever eating,
2. Have I not neede, that muſt feede ſo many
Cannibals, as will waite on me whether I will or no?
3. Heres one in my necke, I would'twere on thy ſhoulder.
1. Keepe it your ſelfe, I have retainers enow of mine owne.
2. But, whether are you going now?
1. Why, are you our King, and doe not know that?
2. Your King? I am a very rogniſh King, and I hav
A companie of lowſie ſubiects.
2. But looke about my ragged ſubiects here comes ſome body,
1. O the devills, ſhall we aske them an almes?
2. Why not, now the rats haue eaten up their brother Biſhop, they will be more charitable, your vecation you ſlaves.
3. For the Lord ſake be pittifull to a companie of poore men.

sp.speaker: Hatto.
sp.l: What cry is this? beggars ſo neere the doore
Of our deceaſed brother; whip them hence,
Or bring the Maſtiffe foorth, worry them,
They are lazie drones, 'tis pittie ſuch ſhould live.
1. I told you my Lord how we ſhould find them: whip us,
Leade the way ſoveraigne, weele none of your whipping.

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: Hence with theſe dogs, what make they neere this houſe?
2. He will be eaten with rats too, he looks like a piece of cheeſe alreadie.

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: You Rogues.

sp.speaker: Alf.
sp.l: Good brother ſtay your ſelfe from wrath,
Thinke on the Biſhop and his odious death.

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: What odious death I pray?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Eaten with Rats,
Whileſt he was liuing, for the wrong he did
Vnto the poore, the branches of our God.

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: Tis true, and therefore call the poore againe,
Come hither friends, I did forget my ſelfe.
Pray for me, ther's ſome ſilver for thy wants.
2. Now the Lord bleſſe you, and keep your good fate.
From being Mouſe-eaten, wee came thinking
Wee ſhould have ſome dole at the Biſhops funerall,
But now this ſhall ſerve our turne, wee will
Pray for you night and day.

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: Goe to the backe gate, and you ſhall have dole.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: O the Lord ſave thee.

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: Theſe Beggers pray and curſe, both in a breath,
Oh wherefore ſhould we fawne upon ſuch curres,
The mice of mankind, and the ſcorne of earth?

sp.speaker: Alf.
sp.l: So ſaid our brother.

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: And he was a Biſhop,
Had read the Scripture, and knew what he ſaid.

sp.speaker: Alf.
sp.l: But he hath brought that ſaying with his death,
With ſuch a loathſome and notorious death,
As while the World's a World, 'twill ſpeake of Meath.

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: The Lord Archbiſhop of Meath, and die by Rats.

sp.speaker: Alf.
sp.l: He did proclaime reliefe unto the poore,
Aſſembled them unto a private Barne,
And having lockt the doore, ſet it on fire,
Saying, hee'de rid the countrie of ſuch Mice,
And Mice and Rats have rid him from the World:

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: Well, Ile not hurt the poore ſo publikely,
But privately I'le grinde their very hearts,
Torture them living, and yet have their prayers,
And by ſuch meanes, that few or none ſhall know it.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: In ſuch a courſe Alfred would wind with you,
For though I counſail'd you to be more calme,
Twas not in pittie of their povertie,
But to auoide their clamour, to give nothing,
Will make them curſe you: but to threaten them,
Flie in your face, and ſpit upon your beard,
No devill ſo fierce, as a bread-wanting heart,
Eſpecially being baited with ill tearmes,
But what courſe can you take to plague theſe dogges?

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: Why, buy up all the corne, and make a dearth,
So thouſands of them will die under ſtalles.

sp.speaker: Alf.
sp.l: And ſend it unto forraine nations,
To bring in toies, to make the wealthy poore.

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: Or make our land beare wood inſtead of wheate.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Incloſe the commons, and make white meates deare.

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: Turne paſture into Parke grounds, and ſtarve cattle,
Or twentie other honeſt thriving courſes;
The meaneſt of theſe, will beggar halfe a Kingdome.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I have a commiſsion drawne for making glaſſe,
Now if the Duke come, as I thinke he will;
Twill be an excellent meanes to laviſh wood,
And then the cold will kill them, had they bread.

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: The yron Mills are excellent for that,
I have a pattent drawne to that effect,
If they goe up, downe goes the goodly trees,
Ile make them ſearch the earth to find new fire.

sp.speaker: Alf.
sp.l: We two are brothers, and the Duke's our brother,
Shall we be brothers in Commiſsion?
And Ile perſwade him to authorize thee
His ſubſtitute in Meath, when he enioyes it.

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: Death Ile get thee Regent under him
In Saxonie, to oppreſſe as well as I,
And we will ſhare the profits, live like Kings,
And yet ſeeme liberall in common things.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Content, what though the Rats devour'd our brother?
Was not a Prophet murdered by a Lyon?
King Herod died of Lice, wormes doe eate us all,
The Rats are wormes, then let the Rats eate me,
Is the dead courſe prepar'd?

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: Embalm'd and coffin'd,
The Citie keyes delivered to my hands,
We ſtay but onely for his Excellence.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: The Duke is comming if it pleaſe your honors.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: And he is welcome, let the trumpets found.

div.stage: Enter Duke of Saxon, Euphrata, and Iulia.

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: Welcome, thrice welcome our renowned brother,
Loe at thy feete, the Citizens of Meath,
By us their Agents, do lay downe the keyes,
And by this crownet, and ſword reſign'd,
The ſtate Maieſtique to your Princely hands,
Diſcended to you, by our brothers death.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Then with your loves, and perſons we receive it,
Is then our brother the Archbiſhop dead?

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: Too true my Lord.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: I am ſorry for my Vncle.

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: And of a death ſo publike by reporte.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Devour'd by Rats, in ſtrange and wonderous ſort.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Could not this palace ſeated in the Rheine,
In midſt of the great River, (to the which
No bridge, nor convay, other then by boats,
Was to be had) ree him from vermine Rats?

sp.speaker: Alf.
sp.l: Againſt their kind, the land Rats took the water
And ſwomme in little armies to the houſe,
And though we drownd, and kild innumerable,
Their numbers were like Hydra's heads increaſing,
Ruine bred more untill our brother died.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: The houſe is execrable, Ile not enter.

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: You need not feare my Lord, the houſe is free,
From all reſort of Rats, for at his death,
As if a trumpet founded a retreat,
They made a kind of murmure, and departed.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Sure 'twas the hand of heaven, for his contempt
Of his poore creatures: but what writs are thoſe?

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: Commiſſions (if it pleaſe your grace) for glaſſe
For yron Mines, and other needfull things.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Our ſelfe inveſted in the government
The Cities care, ſhall lie upon your care.

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: Alfred our brother may awaite your grace ſeven,
in Saxony, ſo pleaſe you to command.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: We are now but three, that lately have bin
We have cauſe to love each other, for my part,
Betweene you both, we give a brothers heart,
Here, or at Saxonis, command at pleaſure,
I weare the corronet, be yours the treaſure.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: We thanke our brother.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Where's my ſonne Fredericks?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Father, the ſtate of Meath deſire your grace.
To take the paines to paſſe unto the Senate.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What glove is that ſon Fred. in your hand!

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: I found it if it pleaſe your Excellence,
Neere to the ſtate-houſe, the imbroiderie
Is very excellent, and the faſhion rare.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I have not ſeene a prettier forme of hand?
Daughter let's ſee, is't not too bigge for you?

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Sure 'tis ſome admirable worke of nature,
If it fit any hand that owes this glove,
If all the reſt doe parallel the hand.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Will it not on?

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Not for a diadem,
Ile trie no longer, leſt I ſhame my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Try Iulia.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: My hand's bigger then my Ladies.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I cannot tell, but in my minde I feele
A wondrous paſſion of I know not what.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: The imbroidered glove may be ſome childs no womans

sp.speaker: Duke,
sp.l: I ſhould miſtruſt as much, but that this place
Beares greater compaſſe then a childiſh hand,
I muſt command it.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Willingly my Lord.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Then to the ſtate-houſe brothers lead the way.
Firſt our inſtalement, then a funerall day.

div.stage: Exeunt Duke and brothers, and Fred.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: Yonder ſhe goes, the mirrour of her ſexe,
Stay beauteous Euphrata.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Otho, what Iulia?

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: Here Madam, what's your will.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Call Conſtantine,
Tell him, his deare friend Otho is return'd.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: Stay Iulia.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Doe as I bid you, goe.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: I had rather have a word or twaine with you.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: I have heard him oft enquire for thee his friend,
I have heard him ſigh, I have ſeene him weepe for thee,
Imagining ſome miſchiefe, or diſtreſſe
Had falne thee ſince the cloſets ſeparation.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: And what a ſlave am I to wrong this friend.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: The welcom'ſt man alive,
Vnkind, how couldſt thou ſtay from me ſo long?

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: I have bin ill at eaſe, pray pardon me,
But I reioyce to ſee my friend ſo well.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Some Ladies love hath made him melancholy.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: Shee hath read the letter that I lately ſent her,
In a pomegranat, by thoſe words I hope.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Why ſpeak you not, is't love, or melancholy?

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: If upon love my griefe is melancholy.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Ile haue the beſt Phiſitians here in Meath.
Aſſay by art to cure that malladie.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Gainſt mellancholy minds your onely Phiſick
Our Saxon doctors hold that principle,
Now I remember you did lately ſend me
A choice pomegranate, fetch it Iulia,
Some of thoſe graines well ſtir'd in Gaſcoine wine,
Is preſent remedie.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: Madam, Ile none
Of all fruits, that I hate.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: And commended it ſo highly by the meſſenger that brought it.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Twas well remembred, you ſhall take a graine.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: You will but vexe me.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: So his melancholly
Doth make him froward with his deareſt friend,
Tis well done Iulia, quickely cut it up,
And bring a cup of wine, or let me doo't.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: I ſee I ſhall be plagu'd with mine owne wit:
Being aſham'd to ſpeake, I writ my minde,
Were you my friends, you would not martyr me
With needleſſe phiſicke, fie upon this traſn,
The very ſight is loathſome.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Take it up.
But let me ſee, what letter's that that dropt,
Came it from you, or from the Spaniſh fruit.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Tis all the graines that the pomegranate had.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Then ther's ſome trechery within theſe grains,
Ile breake it up,
And 'tis directed to my Euphrata.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: What may the tenure be, I pray thee reade it.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: O fall upon me ſome wind-ſhaken turrer,
To hide me from the anger of my friend,
O from his frowne, becauſe he is my friend,
Were he an enemie, I would be bold.
But kindnes makes this wound; ô this horror,
The words of friends are ſtronger then their power.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Withdraw good Iulia.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: 'Pray what is it love?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Tis love indeed to thee, but to my heart
Every looſe ſentence is a killing dart.
I brought this Gorges to my hearts delight.
And he hath drown'd his ſenſes with the ſight,
Except thy ſelfe, all things to him were free,
Otho, thou haſt done me more then iniurie,
Well maiſt thou fixe thy eye vpon the earth,
This action fith breedes a prodigious birth,
It is ſo monſtrous and againſt all kinde,
That the lights ſplendor would confound thy minde.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: I have offended, prethee pardon me.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: What cauſe did move thee?

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: Her all-conquering ſight.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Couldſt thou uſurpe upon my well known right?

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: Thinke I am fleſh and blood, and ſhe is faire.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Thinke how I love thee.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: There proceeds my care.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Our amitie hath bin of ancient dayes,
During which time, wrong'd I thee any wayes?

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: Never.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: But rather I have done thee good.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: I grant you have, ô rather ſhed my blood,
Then number the kind deedes betweene us paſt,
For this unkindneſſe here I love my laſt.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: He doth repent, and will renounce his ſuite,

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: I doe renounce it.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: O thou canſt not do't.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: Suffer me ſtay a while in her faire ſight,
'T will heale my wound and all love baniſh quite.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: The ſight of the belov'd, makes the deſire
That burnt but ſlowly, flame like ſparkling fire.
As thou doſt love me, take thee to ſome place,
Where thou maiſt nere ſee her, nor I thy face.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: By what is deere betwixt us, by our ſelves,
I vow hencefoorth ten thouſand deaths to prove,
Then be a hinderance to ſuch vertuous love.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Breake heart, tis for thy ſake.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: When I am dead,
O then forget that I haue iniured.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: O hell of love.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: Or rather hell of friends.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Firmely till they love.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: Then thus all friendſhip ends.

div.head: Actus Secundus.
div.stage: Enter Duke, Fredericke, Hatto and Alfred.

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: Good brother heare ſome Muſicke, twill delight you.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Ile call the Actors, will you ſee a play?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Or gracious father, ſee me runne the race,
On a light footed horſe, ſwifter then winde.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I pray forbeare.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: This moode will make you mad,
For melancholy Vſhers franticke thoughts.

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: It makes hot wreaking blood turne cold and drie,
And drithe and coldneſſe are the ſignes of death.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You doe torment me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Is it any thing
That I have done, offends your grace?

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: Or comes this hidden anger from my fault?

sp.speaker: Alf.
sp.l: Heres none but gladly would reſigne his life,
To doe you pleaſure, ſo pleaſe you to command.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Ifaith you are too blame to vexe me thus.

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: Then grounds this ſorrow on your brothers death?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Or rather on the glove I lately found.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: A plague vpon the glove, whats that to me,
Your prating makes me almoſt lunatike.
As you reſpect my welfare, leave me, leave me,
The ſooner you depart, the ſooner I
Shall finde ſome meanes to cure my maladie.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Our beſt courſe is to be obedient.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Farewell,
Was ever ſlave beſotted like to me,
That Kings have lou'd, thoſe that they never ſaw,
Is nothing ſtrange, ſince they have heard their praiſe,
Birds that by painted grapes have bin deceiu'd,
Had yet ſome ſhadow to excuſe their error,
Pigmalion that did love an Ivory Nimph,
Had an Idea to delight his ſence,
The youth that doted on Minerva's picture,
Had ſome contentment for his eye
But love, or rather an infernall hagge,
Envying Saxons greatnes and his ioyes,
Hath given me nothing but a trifling glove,
As if by the proportion of the caſe,
Art had the power to know the jewels nature,
Or Nimph, or goddeſſe, woman, or faire devill
If any thing thou art within my braine,
Draw thine owne picture, let me ſee thy face,
To doate thus groſſely, is a groſſe diſgrace.
I heare ſome Muſique, ô ye Deities.
Send you this heavenly conſort from the ſpheares?
To recreate a love-perplexed heart.
The more it founds, the more it refreſheth,
I ſee no inſtruments, nor hands that play,
And my deare brothers durſt not be ſo bold,
'Tis ſome celeſtiall rapture of the minde,
No earthlie harmonie is of this kinde,
Now it doth ceaſe, ſpeake who comes there?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Father.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: From whence proceeds the Muſicke that I heard?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: The beauteous and the famous Curtezan,
Allyed unto the baniſhed Montano,
Admir'd Ʋalontia, with a troope of youths,
This day doth keepe her yeerely feſtiuall,
To all her ſutors, and this way ſhe paſt
Vnto her Arbor, when the Muſique plaide.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Admir'd Ʋalentia, Curtezans are ſtrange
With us in Germanie, except her ſelfe,
Being a Venetian borne, and priviledg'd,
The ſtate allowes none here.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Twere good for Meath ſhe were unpriuiledgd
And ſent to Ʋenice.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Of all the faces that mine eye beheld,
Hers is the brighteſt.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Is ſhe then ſo faire?

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: O beyond all compariſon of beautie.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Vpon her hand,
Father I ſaw the fellow to your glove.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What the imbroidred glove you lately found?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Fellow to that.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Then let it be reſtor'd,
What ſhould a Prince retaine a ſtrumpets glove?
O ye eternall powers, am I inſnar'd
With the affection of a common trull,
Wheres your commiſſions that you would have ſign'd,
'Tis time I had a preſident in Saxonie,
Receive our ſignet, and impreſſe them ſtraight,
Ile remaine here in Meath, ſome little time,
Brother have care my Dukedome be well rul'd,
Here I put over my affaires to you,
My ſonne I leave unto the ioyes of youth,
Tis pittie that his mind ſhould be oppreſt
So ſoone with care of governments,
Goe to your pleaſures, ſeeke your ſiſter foorth,
Send Conſtantine to us, ſo leaue me all,
I am beſt accompanied with none at all.
Either the Plannets that did meete together,
In the grand conſultation of my birth,
Were oppoſite to every good infuſion,
Or onely Venus ſtood as retrograde,
For but in love of this none loving trull,
I have beene fortunate even ſince my birth,
I feele within my breaſt a ſearching fire,
Which doth aſcend the engine of my braine,
And when I ſeeke by reaſon to ſuppreſſe
The heate it gives, the greaters the exceſſe:
I loath to looke upon a common lip.
Were it as corrall as Aurora's cheeke,
Died with the faire virmillion ſunne:
O but I loue her, and they ſay ſhe is faire,
Now Conſtantine.

sp.speaker: Con:
sp.l: Your grace did ſend for me.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Lend me your habit in exchange of mine,
For I muſt walke the Citie for a purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Withall my heart, my habit and my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: In any caſe, watch at the privie chamber.
If any aske for me, ſay I am not well,
And tho it be my ſonne, let him not enter.

sp.speaker: Con
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Be carefull gentle Conſtantine,
Now faire Valentia, Saxon to thy bower,
Comes like a Iove to raine a golden ſhower.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Proſper kind Lord, what ere the action be,
Counſailes of Princes ſhould be ever free.

sp.speaker: Ʋa.
sp.l: Torches and Muſique there, the room's too darke.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Prethee Neece
Abandon this laſcivious unchaſte life,
It is the onely blemiſh of our houſe,
Scandall unto our name, a Curtezan,
O what's more odious in the eares of men!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Then why doe men reſort to Curtezans,
And the beſt ſort; I ſcorne inferiour groomes.
Nor will I denie to draw aſide my maske,
To any meaner then a Noble man.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Come, can you dance: a caper and a kiſſe,
For every turne, Ile fold thee in my armes,
And if thou fal'ſt although no a kin we be,
That thou maiſt light fall ſoft, Ile fall under thee,
Oh for the lightneſſe of all light heel'd girles.
And I would touch the Ceeling with my lips,
Why art thou ſad Montano?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: On iuſt cauſe,
You know I am baniſh't from my natiue countrey.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: This citie is Meath, thou art of Saxonie.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: But this belongs unto the Saxons Duke:
By the deceaſe of the departed Biſhop.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: Feare not, thou art as ſafe within my houſe,
As if perculliz'd in a wall of braſſe.
Wheres Ʋandermas?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Madam did you call?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: What noble man is that, a ſutor to you?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: An excellent Pander, a rare doore-keeper.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I had thought he had bin a gentleman at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Becauſe of his attire?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: True.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O the attire, in theſe corrupted daies, is no true ſigne
To ſhew the gentleman; peaſants now weare robes
In the habiliments of noblemen.
The world's grovvn naught, ſuch iudgement then is baſe,
For Hares and Aſſes we are the Lions caſe.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: 'Tis very coſtly and exceeding rich.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Riches to me, are like traſh to the poore,
I haue them in abundance, gold's my ſlave,
I keepe him priſoner in a three-fold cheſt,
And yet his kindred daily viſit me.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Lord how diligent
Is this rich clothed fellow!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Were he proud,
And ſhould but dare to ſtand ſtill when I call,
I'de runne him through with a killing frowne.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Why then belike his ſervice is for love.

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.l: Why ſo are all the ſervants that attend mee,
They keepe themſelves in ſattin, velvets, gold,
At their owne charge, and are diligent,
Daies, moneths, and yeeres, to gaine an amorous ſmile.
Looke on my face with an indifferent eye.
And thou ſhalt finde more muſicke in my lookes,
Then in Amphions Lute, or Orpheus Harpe,
Mine eye conſiſts of numbers like the ſoule,
And if there be a ſoule, tis in mine ey,
For of the harmonie theſe bright ſtarres make,
I comprehend the formes of all the world,
The ſtory of the Syrens in my voyce,
Is onely verified, for Millions ſtand
In chanted, when I ſpeake, and catch my words,
As they were orient pearle to adorne their eares,
Circe is but a fable, I transforme
The vertuous, valiant, and the moſt preciſe,
Into what forme of minde my fancie pleaſe,
Thou might'ſt bee proud great Lord of my abundance,
For in this beautie I ſhall more renowne
Our noble progenie, then all the pennes
Of the beſt Poets that ere writ of men.
Vnto your health, a health, let Muſique ſound,
That what I taſte, in Muſique may be drown'd.
So, fill more wine, we vſe to drinke up all,
Wine makes good blood, and cheeres the heart withal.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Madam, at ſuch time as I heard you call,
A gentleman it ſeemes of good diſcent,
Humblie did craue acceſſe unto your honor,

sp.speaker: Ʋalen.
sp.l: What did he give?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: A brace of bags of gold.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.l: He ſhall have libertie to enter ſtraight.
But firſt inrich the chamber with perfumes.
Burne choice Arabian Drugs more deare then
Waters diſtil'd out of the ſpirit of Flowers,
And ſpread our coſtly Arras to the eye.
My ſelfe ſufficiently doe ſhine in jems,
Where ſuch faire coated Heraulds doe proceed,
It ſeemes he is honorable and of noble ſame.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Shall I behold this ſutor?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.l: At the full,
At pleaſure paſſe through every ſpacious Roome,
Be he a Prince, Ile know his high diſcent.
Or proudly ſcorne to give him his content,
What drum is that?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: A Maske ſent by a friend.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.l: Belike our ſelfe muſt know the myſterie,
Tell them we are prepar'd to ſee the Maske,
And bid the other noblemen come neere,
Thus am I hourely viſited by friends,
Beautie's a counſellor that wants no fee,
They talke of circles and of powerfull ſpells,
Heres heavenly art, that all blacke art excells,

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Ile walke into the farther gallery.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.l: Sir you are welcome what ſo ere you be,
I gueſſe your birth great by your bounteous fee.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Your humble ſervant bound by a ſweet kiſſe.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.l: I give you freedome gentle Sir by this.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: I know your mind, firſt cenſure of the ſport,
Then you and I will enter Venus Court.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: More then immortall, ô more then divine,
That ſuch perfection ſhould turne Concubine.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: That voice is like unto the Saxon Dukes,
I feare he hath heard I liu'd here in this place,
And he is come to doe me more diſgrace,
Montano hide thy ſelfe till he be gone,
His daughter thirſts for my deſtruction.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Come ſit by me, the Maskers are at hand,
Where are my Maides, to helpe to make the dance?

div.stage: They dance, Valentia with them, they whiſper to to have her play at dice, and ſtake on the drum.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.l: VVhat ſhall we have a Mumming? heres my jewell.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Thou art a iewell moſt incomparable,
Malicious heaven, why from ſo ſweete a face
Have you exempt the mind adorning grace?

div.stage: She wins, the drum ſtrikes up.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: More gold, for this is mine, I thanke yee dice

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: And ſo are all that doe behold thy beautie,
Were ſhe as chaſte as ſhe is outward bright,
Earth would be heaven, and heaven eternall night,
The more I drinke of her delicious eye,
The more I plunge into captivitie.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.l: Have I wonne all? then take that back agen,
What ſcorne my gift, I ſee you are gentlemen,
No, is't not poſſible that I may know,
Vnto whoſe kindneſſe this great debt I owe?
Well, Ile not be importunate, farewell,
Some of your gold let the torch-bearers tell.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Beauteous Madona, do you know theſe galants?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.l: I gueſſe them of the Duke of Saxons Court.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: My ſubiects, and ſo many my corrivalls,
O every ſlave is grac't before his Prince.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.l: Are you not well ſir, that your colour fades.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: If I be ſicke, 'tis onely in the minde,
To ſee ſo faire, ſo common to all kinde.
I am growne iealous now of all the world,
Lady how ere you prize me, without pleaſure,
More then a kiſſe, I tender you this treaſure.
O what's a mint ſpent in ſuch deſire,
But like a ſparke that makes a greater fire?
She muſt be made my Dutches, there it goes,
And marrying her, I marry thouſand woes.
Adiew kind Miſtreſſe, the next nevves you heare,
Is to ſit crown'd in an Imperiall crowne.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.l: Either the man diſlikes me, or his braine,
Is not his owne to give, ſuch gifts in vaine.
But 'tis the cuſtome in this age to caſt
Gold upon gold, to encourage men to waſte,
Lightly it comes, and it ſhall lightly flie.
Whilſt colours hold, ſuch preſents cannot die.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: But this is ſtrange, that I ſhould have her honour?
So farre from Court, pray whither were you riding?

sp.speaker: Alf.
sp.l: Vnto your mannor, heard you not the newes.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: What newes?

sp.speaker: Alf.
sp.l: This morning by the breake of day,
His excellence ſent to me by a poſt,
Letters, by which the pillars of the ſtate
Should be aſſembled to a Parliament,
Which he intends my Lords, to hold in Meath.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: When if it pleaſe your honor?

sp.speaker: Alf.
sp.l: Inſtantly, withall the haſt that winged time can make.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: Sooner the better,
Tis like the realmes affaires are of ſome weight.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I will bee there to night,
And ſo I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Reinal.
sp.l: We take our leaves.

sp.speaker: Alf.
sp.l: Farewell my honor'd friend,
There is within my braine a thouſand wiles,
How I may heape up riches, ô the ſight
Of a gold ſhining Mountaine doth exceede,
Silver is good, but in reſpect of gold,
Thus I eſteeme it.

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: How now my friends, what are you?
1. Poore petitioners.

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: Stand farther then, the poore is as unpleaſing Vnto me as the plague.
sp.p: 2. An't pleaſe your good Lordſhip, I am a Merchant and gladly would convay a thouſand quarters of wheate and other graine over the ſea, and heres a hundred pounds for a commiſſion.

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: Thou art no beggar, thou ſhalt ha't my friend, Give me thy money.
sp.p: 3. I an't pleaſe your honour have a commoditie of good broad cloth, not paſt two hundred, may I ſhippe them over, and theres a hundred poundes.

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt have leave.
1. Although I ſeeme a poore petitioner,
My Lord I crave a warrant to tranſport
A hundred Cannons, fiftie Culverings,
VVith ſome ſlight armours, halberts, and halfe pikes,
And theres as much as any of the reſt.

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: Away Cannibal, wouldſt thou ſhip ordnance?
What though we ſend unto the foes our corne,
To fatten them, and cloth to keepe them warme,
Lets not be ſo forgetfull of our ſelves
As to provide them knives to cut our throates,
So I ſhould arme a thiefe to take my purſe,
Haſt thou no other courſe of Merchandize?
Thou ſhouldſt get gold, twill yeeld thee ten in the hundred
On bare exchange, and raiſe the price with vs,
Make us for want, coyn, braſſe, and paſſe it currant,
Vntill we find profit to call it in,
There are a thouſand waies to make thee thrive,
And Ile allow of all bee it nere ſo bad,
Excepting guns to batter downe our houſes.
1. Letters of Mart I humblie then intreate,
To ceaſe on Rovers that doe ſcoure the ſeas.

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: And on our friends too, if thou canſt do't cleanlie,
Spare none, but paſſe it very cloſely,
VVe will be loath to ſift thy Piracie.
But open care to heare what they complaine,
Haſt thou a Letter?
1. Ready drawne my Lord,
And heres a brace of hundred pounds for you.

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: 'Tis very well, I thinke I ſhall be rich,
If dayly tenants pay me rent thus faſt,
Giue me your licenſes, they ſhall bee ſeal'd,
About an houre hence, here attend our pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: VVe thanke your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: O vild catterpillers,
And yet how neceſſarie for my turne,
I have the Dukes ſeale for the Citie Meath,
VVith which Ile ſigne their warrants,
This corne and twentie times as much
Alreadie covertly convai'd to France,
And other bordering Kingdomes neere the ſea,
Cannot but make a famine in this land,
And then the poore like dogs will die apace,
Ile ſeeme to pittie them, and give them almes,
To blind the world, 'tis excellent policie,
To rid the land of ſuch, by ſuch denice,
A famine to the poore, is like a froſt
Vnto the earth, which kills the paltry wormes,
That would deſtroy the harveſt of the ſpring,
As for the which, I count them painefull men
VVorthy to enioy what they can get,
Beggars are traſh, and I eſteeme them ſo,
Starve, hang, or drowne themſelves, I am alive,
Looſe all the world, ſo I have wit to thrive,
But I muſt to the Parliament, and then
Ile have a clauſe to beggar ſome rich meu.

div.head: Actus Tertius.
div.stage: Enter Duke, Fredericke, Conſtantine, Reinaldo, Alberto, Alfrid, and amongſt them Hatto ſhuffles in.

sp.speaker: Alberto.
sp.l: Princes and pillars of the Saxon State.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You are the elected, ſpeake for the Court,
Stay Lord Alberto, we uſurpe your office,
Who had the charge to fetch Valentia.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I gracious Lord, and when I gave the charge,
A ſudden ſcare by paleneſſe was diſplar'd
Vpon her roſie cheeke, the crimſon blood,
That like a robe of ſtate did beautifie
The goodly buildings with a two fold grace,
From either ſide ſhrunke downewards to her heart,
As if thoſe ſummons were an adverſarie,
And had ſome mighty crime to charge her with,
Millions of thoughts were crowded in her braines,
Her troubled minde, her abrupt words deſcrib'd,
She did accuſe her ſelfe without accuſers,
And in the terrour of a ſoule perplext,
Cry'd out, the Duke intends to ceaſe my goods,
Cauſe I am noted for a Concubine,
I did replie ſuch comfort as beſeemes,
But comfortleſſe I brought her to the Court.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Then ſhe attends our pleaſure?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Mightie Lord in the next Roome.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You are carefull Conſtantiue,
Conduct her in, and Lords give mee your thoughts,
What thinke ye wee intend to Ʋalentia?

sp.speaker: Alf.
sp.l: Her ſelfe hath read my ſentence in the ſpeech,
That Conſtantine delivered to your grace.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: What ſhould my noble father thinke,
But that ſhee is a ſtrumpet, and in that,
A blemiſh to the ſtate wherein ſhe lives.

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: She is rich in iewells, and hath ſtore of treaſure,
Got by the ſlavery of that choice beautie,
Which otherwiſe admires her to the world.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Confiſcate all her goods unto the Crown,
Thereby diſburdening many heavie taxes.
Impos'd upon the commons of the land.

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: Publique example make her to all ſuch
Offences in that kind are growne too common,
Leſſe ſhameleſſe now were the beautious dames
Of Meath and Saxony, when the ſufferance
Hath at this inſtant made them good my Lord,
Enact ſome mighty penaltie for luſt.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: How wide theſe Archers ſhoote from the faire aime
Of my affection: bring Valentia in.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.l: The duetie that in generall I doe owe
Vnto your excellence and to this Court,
I pay at once upon my bended knee.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Behold her Princes with impartiall eyes,
And tell me, looks ſhe not exceeding faire?

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: If that her mind coher'd with her faire face,
Shee were the worthy wonder of this age.

sp.speaker: Alfred.
sp.l: I never ſaw a beautie more divine,
Groſſely deform'd by her notorious luſt.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Faireneſſe and wantonneſſe haue made a match
To dwell together, and the worſt ſpoyles both.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: Shee is doubly excellent in ſin and beauty.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: That they ſpeake truth my conſcience ſpeaks,
But that I loue her that I ſpeake my ſelfe:
Stand up divine deformitie of nature,
Beautious corruption, heavenly ſeeing evill,
What's excellent in good and bad ſtand up,
And in this Chaire prepared for a Duke,
Sit my bright Dutcheſſe, I command thee ſit:
You looke I am ſure for ſome apologie,
In this raſh action; all that I can ſay
Is that I loue her, and wil marry her.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: How, loue a Lais, a baſe Rodophe,
Whoſe body is as common as the Sea
In the receipt of every luſtfull ſpring?

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: The elements of which theſe orbes conſiſts
Fire, ayre, and water, with the good we tread
Are not more vulgar, common, popular
Then her imbracements.

sp.speaker: Alberto.
sp.l: To inch • yne the thoughts
Vnto this diſſemblance of laſcivious loue
Were to be maried to the broad rode way,
Which doth receiue the impreſſion of every kind.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Speech doth want modeſty to ſet her forth
In her true forme, baſe and contemptible,
The very hindes and peaſants of the land
Will bee Corrivals with your excellence,
If you eſpouſe ſuch a notorious Trull.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: We ſhall haue luſt a vertue in the Court:
The wayes of ſinne be furthered by reward:
Panders and Paraſites ſit in the places
Of the wiſe Counſellors and hurry all.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Father as you are princely in your birth,
Famous in your eſtate, belou'd of all
And (which ads greateſt glory to your greatneſſe)
Eſteem'd wiſe: Shew not ſuch open folly,
Such palpable, ſuch groſſe, ſuch mountaine folly,
Be not the By-word of your neighbour Kings,
The ſcandall of your Subiects, and the triumph
Of Lenos mathrens and the hatefull ſtewes:
Why ſpeake you not that are his brother friends,
You that doe weare the Liveries of time,
The ſilver cognizance of gravitie?
Shall none but young me ſchoole? the reverent old
Birds teach the Dam, ſtars fill the glorious ſpheares
Of the all lightning Sunne, ſpeake whilſt you may,
Or this raſh deede will make a fatall day.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You haue ſaid too much, encourage none to ſpeake
More then haue ſpoke; by my royall blood,
My mind's eſtabliſht not to be withſtood,
Thoſe that applaude my choyſe giue us your hands,
And helpe to tye theſe ſacred nuptiall bands.

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: What likes your excellence, likes me well.

sp.speaker: Alfred.
sp.l: And I agree to what my Soveraigne pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Theſe are no brothers, they are flatterers,
Contrary to themſelues in their owne ſpeech,
You that doe loue the honour of your Prince
The care and long life of my father,
The hereditary right deriv'd to me,
Your countries Welfare and your owne renowne,
Lend me your hands to plucke her from the throne.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.l: Princes forbeare, I doe not ſeeke the match,
It is his highneſſe pleaſure I fit here,
And if he loue me tis no fault of mine,
Behoues me to be thankefull to his Grace,
And ſtriue in vertue to deſerue this place.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Thou ſpeak'ſt too mildly to theſe hare braind youthes:
He that preſumes to plucke her from the chaire
Dyes in the attempt, this ſword ſhall end all care.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Why, ſhee's notorious.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: But ſhe will amend.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis too farre growne to haue a happy end.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: The dangerous the diſeaſe greater's the cure.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Princes may ſeeke renowne by wayes more ſure,
Shee is diſhoneſt.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Honeſtie's vnſeene,
Shee's faire, and therefore fit to be a Queene.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: But vertue is to be preferd ere luſt.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Thoſe that are once falſe ſhal we ne're truſt?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Wiſe men approue their actions by the tryall.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I ſay ſhe is mine in ſpight of all deniall.
Bring me the Crowne.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: To ſet upon her head?
Friends draw your ſwords firſt ſtrike the ſtrumpet dead.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: My guard, my guard.

sp.speaker: Alfred.
sp.l: For ſhame put up your ſwords.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: For ſhame great Rulers leaue your flattering words.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: 'Tis madneſſe in the King, and worſe in you.

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: Though you proue traytors we'le not proue untrue.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Will you diſmiſſe this Strumpet to the ſtewes,
Or our allegance in this act refuſe.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Doe what you dare, the election ſtill ſhall ſtand.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Woe and deſtruction then muſt rule the land.
Come Lord Rinaldo, valiant Alberto come,
We haue friends enough to grace a warlike Drum.
Hearke how the Commons doe applaud our cauſe,
Laſcivious Duke, farewell father, oh vilde,
Where Queanes are mothers, Fredericke is no child.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: My guard purſue them, and aliue or dead,
Cut off the cauſe by which theſe cries are bred,
Come my faire Dutcheſſe firſt unto the Church,
There ſollemnize our nuptials, then unto our armes,
A little rough breath over beares theſe ſtormes.

sp.speaker: Alfred.
sp.l: The Duke's beſotted now we are ſecure,
This match makes well for us, we may command,
And on them lay the abuſes of the land.

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: Excellent good, we are like to haue warres indeed,
But in the meane the poore will ſtarue for bread,
Wee muſt ſhare proffits howſoere things goe
Winner, or looſer, neither is our foe,
For mutually we'le beare our ſelues in all,
Or taking part leane to the ſtrongeſt wall.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: My father married to a Concubine,
Then hee will pardon though I marry thee,
And howſoe'r, about it preſently,
The rather for Montano is repealde
Becauſe of his alliance to Ʋalentia.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I am ready gentle loue and glad in mind
That my faire Euphrata will proue ſo kind.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Come my deare Conſtantine performe this right,
And arme in arme thus will we ſleepe to night.

div.stage: Enter Fredericke, Rinaldo, and Alberto with Drum, Colours, and Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: You that are carefull of your countries weale,
Fellow compere, Supporter of the State,
Let us imbrace in ſteele, our cauſe is good,
What mind ſo baſe that would not ſhed his blood
To free his countrey from ſo great an ill,
As now raignes in it by laſcivious will,
Our friends to warre, and for my part,
Ere luſt beare ſway Ile gladly yeeld my heart.

sp.speaker: Alberto.
sp.l: I heare the Duke is ſtrong.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Suppoſe him ſo,
And be advis'd ſtrongly to meete the foe:
I had rather you ſhould think him ten thouſand ſtrong,
Then find it ſo to our deſtruction,
An enemy thought many and found few,
When our firſt courage failes giues us a new.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: That's the Dukes Drum.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: They are welcome to their death,
The ground they tread on covers them with earth.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: The enemy ſends forth a Champion,
To encounter me, I heard him uſe my name,
The honour of the combate ſhall be mine.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Come boy retreate not, only I intend,
With thy lifes loſſe this bloody warre to end.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: My naturall father in my blood I feele,
Paſſion more powerfull then that conquering ſteele.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Why doſt thou pauſe baſe boy thy Soveraigne's come,
To inter the life I gaue thee, in this tombe.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: My father, oh my father: nature be ſtill,
That I may haue my fame, or he his will.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: What doſt thou feare thy cauſe, is't now ſo evill?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I am poſſeſt with a relenting devill;
Legions of kinde thoughts haue ſurpriz'd my ſenſe,
And I am too weake to be mine owne defence.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Thou art a coward.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: And you make me ſo:
For you come charm'd like a diſhonour'd foe,
You haue conferr'd with ſpirits, and tane their aydes
To make me weake, by them I am betraid,
My ſtrength drawne from me by a ſlight,
What other meanes could hold me from the fight?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I haue no ſpells about me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Tis vntrue,
For naturall Magique you haue brought with you,
And ſuch an exorciſme in your name,
That I forbeare the combate to my ſhame:
But that I am no coward, from your hoſt
Elect two of the valiantſt that dare moſt,
Double that number, treble it, or more,
I haue heart at will t'encounter with a ſcore.
Or had your ſelfe come in a ſtrange attire,
One of us twaine had loſt his living fire.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Ile trie your valour: ſee audacious boy,
Thou art incompaſt with a world of foes,
Montano, Alfred Vandermas and all,
My Dutcheſſe comes too to, behold thy fall.
If thou haſt ſpirit enough, now craue her ayd,
Never was poore ventrous ſouldier worſe apayd.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: My deſire now from the skie of ſtarres,
Dart all your Deitie, ſince I am beſet,
In honourable wiſe payes all Natures debt.

div.stage: They fight, Fredericke beats them off, and courſes the Dutcheſſe over the ſtage.

div.head: Actus quartus.
div.stage: Enter Duke, Montano, Valentia, Hatto and Alfred, Drumme, Colours and Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Our anger long agoe, renowned Lords,
Is ſatisfied in faire Valentias loue.
Behold our proud ſonne and theſe traiterous crew,
That dares confront us in the field of Mars.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.l: You haue been too patient, my beloved Lord,
In calming theſe tumultuous jarring ſpirits:
Scourge them with ſteele, and make the proudeſt know,
Tis more then death to haue their Prince their foe.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Bloody conſtraints beſeemes where dutie failes,
And Oratory ceaſing, force prevailes.

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: Peace would doe better, ſo it pleas'd your ſonne.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: In her allurements firſt begun,
Baniſh her from the land, and Ile reſigne.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Learne thine owne dutie traitor, I know mine.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: Then there's no baniſhment.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: None but by death.
Thy head is forfeit for that daring breath.

sp.speaker: Alfred.
sp.l: Submit degenerate and preſumptuous Lord.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: When we are ignorant to weild a ſword.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Never ſhall noble knee bend to this ground,
As long as that vile ſtrumpet liveth crownd.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: I cannot ſtay to heare my loue deprau'd,
In few words is it peace, or ſhall we fight,
Till our deepe wounds ſhall dampe the heavenly light,
Make the ayre purple with the reaking gore.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Fight whilſt life ſerues you, we will nere giue ore,
The graſſe greene pauement ſhall be drownd in blood,
And yet Ile wade to kill her in the flood.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Alarum Drum, madneſſe is on their ſide,
All vertuous counſell is by them defied.
Vpon our part ſtrike Drums, Trumpets proclaime,
Death moſt aſſur'd to thoſe that haue their ſhame.

div.stage: Alarum, fight luſtily and driue away the Duke, Fredericke purſues Valentia, over the ſtage, and takes her, a Retreate ſounded.
Enter at one doore the Duke, Mon, Hatto, and Alfred with Drum and Colours. Enter at the other doore Fredericke leading Valentia priſoner, Rinaldo and Alberto with Drum and Colours.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Why doe traitors ſound retreat ſo ſoone?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Behold the cauſe.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Valentia priſoner?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: The firebrand of this tumultuous warre,
The originall from whence your ſubjects bloud
Flowes in abundance of this ſpatious play.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.l: And what of all this?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: That thy lifes too meane
To ſatisfie the unworthieſt of the Campe,
For the effuſion of a loyall drop.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Meanes Fredericke then to kill his fathers heart,
In faire Valentia's death?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Not touch your hand, other
Then humble as becomes a ſonne:
But ſhee ſhall ſuffer for enchanting you.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.l: I am a Dutcheſſe, ſet my ranſome downe.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: A dutcheſſe! whence proceeds that borowed name?
Of what continuance? ſcarcely hath the Sunne
Beheld thy pride a day, but doth decline,
Shaming to view a crowned Concubine.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: In mine owne honour Fredericke,
I command thou ſet a ranſome on Valentia.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: What honor's that? your Dukedomes intereſt?
Your princely birth? your honourable fame?
All theſe are blemiſht with a ſtrumpets name.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Be not ſo cruell to bereaue her life,
'Twill draw upon thee a perpetuall ſcar:
Thy fathers curſe, and a continuall warre.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Oh doe not threaten, Fredericke is ſo mild,
He will not proue ſuch a degenerate child:
I cannot blame him tho' hee riſe in armes,
'Twas not in hate to me, but in disdaine,
That I ſhould ſell my royaltie ſo vaine,
But did he know the value of the iem,
Hee would not craſe it for a Dyadem:
That ſhee was common her owne words approue,
But many faults are cover'd where men loue,
As thou reſpects my bleſsing and good dayes,
Reſtore her Fredericke and augment her prayſe.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Reſtore her?

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: Never.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Albert Thou wert kind and I ne're wrong'd thee,
Doe not change thy minde.

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: You doe abaſe your honour to intreate.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: How can I chooſe my affection is ſo great.

sp.speaker: Alfred.
sp.l: Your power is ſtrong, the enemy is but weake.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: In her deſtruction all my powers will breake,
As thou doſt hope of kindneſſe in thy choyſe,
If ere thou loue, giue eare unto my voice,
Turne not aſide thy eye, the feares I feele,
Makes me to bow where tis thy part to kneele:
Loe vaſſailelike, laying aſide command,
I humbly craue this favour at thy hand,
Let me haue my beloved, and take my ſtate,
My life I undervalue to that rate:
Craue any thing that in my power doth lye,
Tis thine, ſo faire Valentia may not dye.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: My ſoule is griev'd, and it appals my blood,
To ſee my father puſſeld in ſuch mood:
Yet ſhall ſhee dye, Ile doe as I haue ſaid
With mine hand, Ile chop off the Stumpets head.

sp.speaker: Alberto.
sp.l: Kill her my Lord, or let me haue the honour.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Tigers would ſaue her, if they lookt upon her,
Shee is ſo beautifull, ſo heavenly bright,
That ſhee would make them loue her for the ſight,
Thou art more rude then ſuch if thou proceede,
In the execution of ſo vilde a deede:
Remember one thing, I did never loue,
Till thou my Frederick broughtſt that fatall Gloue:
That and the Owners name thou didſt deſcry,
Onely for that cauſe let not my loue dye.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: O gods!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Cannot my kneeling ſerue, my teares prevaile.
When all helpes faile mee, yet this will not faile:
Proffer thy weapon to her beauteous ſide,
And with her heart, my heart I will divide:
Intreaty Ile urge none more then are paſt:
And either now relent or heres my laſt.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Stay, if I ſhould relent; will you agree,
To ſigne our generall pardon preſently?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: By heaven I doe, I freely pardon all,
And a reward I giue in generall.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Then take her, you deſerue her were ſhee better,
Making your Crowne and life to be her Debter.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Welcome a thouſand times, welcome ſweete wife:
Never more deare then now, I haue ſould thy life.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.l: This more then kindneſſe I turne backe to you,
Doubling my chaſt vow to bee ever true.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Then here the warres end, are our fightings mande:
Yet by your leaue Ile ſtand upon my Guard.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Take any courſe you pleaſe, Citie, or Towne,
My royall word Ile keepe by this my Crowne.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Then thus Ile take my leaue.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Since we muſt part,
Farewell my Sonne, all farewell with my heart.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Twas well my Lord, 'twas a good policie,
To gaine your bride, I hope your grace did not meane,
To be thus overrulde by a proud Sonne.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Why thinke you he intends ſome treachery?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Why not, and did releaſe Valentia.
To blind your eyes; hee that could be ſo proud,
To riſe in armes againſt his naturall Father,
Hath courage to doe more when he ſees time.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: But I haue pardon'd that offence by oath.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: It were no periury to make him know,
Hee is your Sonne, and ſonnes a dutie owe:
This ſequeſtration will in time aſpire,
Vnto a flame ſhall ſet your Realme on fire:
Warre when a Subiect hath the meanes of will,
'Tis not enough to ſay he has no will.
For will is alter'd by the place and time,
And hee that's once up, knowes the way to clime:
I ſpeake perchance like a prophetique foole,
But theſe are wiſe can counſaile, with your bride
Wiſedome adviſeth timely to provide.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What thinkes my loue of Frederickes reconcilement?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.l: That he has ſpirit enough to be a traytor:
But I am be holding to him for a life,
And he may brag he gaue your grace a wife:
A good old man, he could not chooſe but feele,
For ſhame ſome ſmall remorſe, to ſee you kneele,
Pray God he gaue me not into your hand.
That he might be the ruine of your land.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Thinkes my loue ſo? but brothers what's your cenſure?

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: I am no Polititian.

sp.speaker: Alfred.
sp.l: Neither I.
Wee are both content to liue quietly.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Hee may be a villaine tho' he be my Sonne.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Why not, and worke your ruine like a foe;
Had he meant well, why did he leaue you ſo?
Your noble heart was free from all deceipt,
But hee's retirde to doe ſome dangerous feate,
When Subiects ſtand upon their guard looke to't,
They haue ſome plot in hand and they will do't.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What courſe is readieſt to prevent ſuch miſchiefe?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Plucke up the fulſome thiſtle in the prime;
Young trees bend lightly but grow ſtrong in time:
Were I the worthieſt to adviſe your honour,
You ſhould purſue him with your ſpredding bands,
Swifter in march then is the lightning flame,
And take him tardy whilſt his plots are tame;
Now to charge on his army queſtionleſſe,
Would driue them all into a great diſtreſſe,
If not confound them, having tane your Sonne,
You may be as kind, and doe as hee hath done:
So ſhall he know himſelfe, and be leſſe proud.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.l: The counſailes good.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: And it ſhall be allowed.
You that doe loue me, ſee the hoſt prepar'd,
To ſcare thoſe traytors that our liues haue ſcarde:
Our armie's many, but their power is free;
Beſides they are traytors, all with us are true:
Sound Drums and trumpets, make the world rebound,
Hearten our friends, and all our foes confound.

div.stage: Enter Montano with two or three Souldiers. Vandarman leading Fredericke bound.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Baſe cowards, traytors, how am I ſurprizde
With theſe bonds? I am a Prince by birth,
And princely ſpirits disdaine ſuch clogs of earth;
Let goe you ſlaues.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Firſt know your fathers pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: You are too bold.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: But you ſhall keepe a meaſure.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Thou blood of common Concubines muſt I,
Be bound by thee, and heire of Saxony?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: It is our pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.l: Haue you caught him ſo?
Now ſhall you waite the mercy we will ſhew:
I was too baſe to be your fathers wife.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: But he ſhall ſue to thee to ſaue his life.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Periurde, ungratefull, unnaturall,
Is this the Pardon given in generall.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Wee'l talke of that hereafter, make him faſt.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.l: Helpe Ʋandermas, our ſelfe will ayding be,
To keepe in awe ſuch ſenſeleſſe trechery.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: My helpe and all to priſon there till death,
Remaine in dureſſe.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Rather ſtop my breath,
Strangle me with theſe cords, priſon to me
Is twenty deaths, I will haue liberty:
Now as you are a father be more kind,
You did not find me in ſo ſterne a mind:
And you forgetfull of the life I ſav'd:
Shall a Dukes Sonne by treaſon thus be ſlau'd?
If you ſuſpect my loue, grant me the fight,
I dare in ſingle combate any knight,
Any adventurer, any pandorus hinde,
To proue my faith of an unfained mind.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Away with him.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I ſee my death's ſet downe,
And ſome adulterous heire muſt weare that Crowne:
To intreate a Rodophe, I had rather dye,
Then haue my life lodg'd in ſuch infamy:
If all my fortunes on her words depend,
Let her ſay kill me, and ſo make an end.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Why ſtay you?

sp.speaker: Vander.
sp.l: Good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Peace untaught Groome:
My heart's ſo great that Ide forerun my doome:
There's no releaſe meant, you haue vowed I ſee,
To dam your ſoules by wilfull periury.
Yet that I am my ſelfe let theſe words ſhew,
To die is naturall, 'tis a death I owe,
And I will pay it with a minde as free,
As I enioyed in my beſt libertie.
But this aſſure your ſelfe, when all is done,
They'l kill the father, that will kill the ſonne.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What's to be done now?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Seale unto his death;
Your warrant nere the ſooner takes effect:
'Twill be a meanes to make him penitent,
And pardon's meet for ſuch as doe repent.
Seeing his fault, hee'l taſte your mercie beſt,
When now he proudly thinkes he is oppreſt.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: A Warrant ſhall be ſign'd, and unto thee
I doe commend it: deale not partially,
If he be ſorry, and in true remorſe
Cancell the Writ, elſe let it haue full force.
Had I ten ſonnes, as I haue onely this,
They ſhould all die ere thou depriv'd of bliſſe:
So great is my affection, my faire wife,
That to ſaue thine Ide frankly giue my life.
Come, weele about it ſtrait, all time ſeemes long,
Where thou haſt found flight cauſe to feare my wrong.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.l: That writ Ile take, and a concluſion trie,
If he can loue he liues, if hate me, die.
For howſoere I ſeeme to ſcorne the man,
Hee's ſomewhat deare in my affection.
Here comes your brothers.

sp.speaker: Alfred.
sp.l: May it pleaſe your grace,
By chance entring into Saint Maries Church
This morne by breake of day, I eſpied
That that I know will vexe your Excellence:
Your daughter Euphrata is married
To the ambitious beggar Conſtantine.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: My daughter married my Chamber-ſquire!

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Your Excellence did baniſh me the land,
Becauſe I did ſuſpect her with that fellow.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: He ſhall be tortur'd with th'extreameſt plague
For his preſumption — Haue you brought them,
That I may kill them with a killing looke.

sp.speaker: Hat.
sp.l: Without direction we haue ventured to lay upon them
Your ſtrict command, and they attend.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Bring the preſumptuous.

div.stage: Enter Constantine and Euphrata, Otho following in diſguiſe.

sp.speaker: Euphr.
sp.l: Forward Conſtantine, our Rites are done,
Thou art my husband: doe not feare his eye,
The worſt it can import is but to die.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Baſe and degenerate.

sp.speaker: Euphr.
sp.l: He is a Gentleman,
'Twas baſe in you to wed a Curtizan.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Her brothers ſpirit right, bold and audacious.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Then I am no baſtard, wherefore ſhould I feare,
The knot is ſacred, and I hold it deare.
I am wedded unto vertue, not to will,
Such bleſſed unions never bring forth ill.
If I offend in diſobedience,
Iudge of the power of loue by your offence.
Father, you haue no reaſon for this ire,
Frowne whilſt you kill us, deſire is deſire.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: A Curtezan? hath that ambitious boy
Taught you ſuch Rethoricke? you ſhall taſte like joy.
I will not reaſon with you, words are vaine,
The fault is beſt diſcerned in the paine.
Your haſtie marriage hath writ downe his death,
And thy proud words ſhall ſeale it with thy breath.
By what is deareſt to mee, here I ſweare,
Both of your heads ſhall grace a fatall beere:
Take them to priſon, Ile not heare a word,
This is the mercie that we will afford,
Since they are growne ſo proud, next morne begun,
Let them be both beheaded with my ſonne.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Short and ſweet, Euphrata, the doome is faire,
We ſhall be ſoone in heaven, there ends my care.
I ſcorne entreatie, and my deare I know,
All ſuch ſlavery thou hateſt ſo.
'Twill be a famous deed for this good man
To kill all's children for a Curtezan.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Wilt thou die with me?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Would I liue in heaven?
Thou art now too high for me, death makes us even.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Looke to your dukedome, thoſe that haſt our fall,
Haue by their avarice almoſt hurried all.
There's a whole Regiſter of the poores crie,
Whilſt they are reading them, imbrace and die.

div.stage: Flings downe her lap full of Petitions. Exeunt Euph. and Conſtant.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Beare them away.
And now let's reade theſe Writes.
What's here? complaints againſt my worthy brothers,
For corne tranſported, Copper money ſtampt,
Our ſubjects goods ceaz'd, and I know not what.
A plague upon this buſie-headed rabble,
We will haue tortures made to awe the ſlaues,
Peace makes them ever proud, and malapert.
They'l be an Overſeer of the State.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.l: And plead reformation to depoſe you.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: True my faire Dutcheſſe, but Ile cut them ſhort.
Rule ſtill deare brothers: take theſe to the fire,
Let me reade ſomewhat that augments deſire,
Authors and golden Poems full of loue,
Such the Petitions are that I approue:
So I may liue in quiet with my wife,
Let fathers, mothers, children, all loſe life.
If thou haue iſſue, in deſpight of fate,
They ſhall ſucceed in our Imperiall ſtate.
Come ſweet to dauncing, then to ſport and play,
Till we haue ruled all our life away.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: O pittifull condition of a Realme,
Where the chiefe ruler is ore-rul'd by pleaſure,
Seeing my friend ſurpriz'd in this diſguiſe,
I followed him to meete the conſequence:
And to my griefe I ſee his marriage rites
Will cut him ſhort of all this earths delights.
What's that to mee, when Conſtantine is dead,
I have ſome hope to attaine her Nuptiall bed.
But ſhee is doom'd as well as hee to die,
Can the Duke act his daughters Tragedie.
It is impoſſible, he will relent,
And Ile perſwade her freely to repent.
Yet 'tis moſt likelie that he will agree
He is ſo farre ſpent in vild tyrannie.
The commons hate him for the wrong he hath done,
(By his brothers meanes) the Nobles for his ſonne.
Famine ſpreads through the land, the people die,
Yet he lives ſenſeleſſe of their miſerie.
Never were ſubiects more miſlead by any,
Nor ever Soveraigne hated by ſo many.
But Conſtantine, to thee I caſt an eye,
Shall all our friendſhip end in enmitie?
Shall I that ever held thee as my life,
Haſten thy death, that I may get thy wife,
Or love or friendſhip, whether ſhall exceed,
Ile explaine your vertue in this following deed.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Have you the inſtruments I gave in charge?

sp.speaker: Ʋand,
sp.l: Wee have.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And reſolution fitting for the purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: All things are ready with our faithfull hearts.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And ſhe that undertakes ſo great an act,
As I intend, had need of faithfull hearts,
This is the priſon, and the jaylor comes
In happy time, where's trayterous Frederick?

sp.speaker: Jaylor.
sp.l: What is your highneſſe pleaſure with the Prince?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Looke there if you can reade?

sp.speaker: Iai
sp.l: O heavenly God, what doe I read, a warrant for his death?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.l: Reſigne your keyes, goe weepe a di • ge or twaine,
But make no clamour with your lamentation.

sp.speaker: Iay.
sp.l: I dare not propheſie what my ſouſe feares.
Yet Ile lament his tragedie in teares.

sp.speaker: Ʋalen.
sp.l: Oft have I ſeene a Nobleman arraign'd,
